docs.lead_paragraph: The Whitman administration will sell New Jersey's Garden State Health Plan to the AmeriChoice Corporation for $15 million, officials said yesterday. The Garden State Health Plan was created in 1987 to provide managed care services to Medicaid recipients, and now serves more than 30,000 low-income people.

headline.main: New Jersey Daily Briefing;State Sells Its Health Plan

docs.lead_paragraph: Two marines are to be court-martialed in Hawaii on Monday for refusing to comply with the military's program of mandatory genetic testing, the first major test of a practice that experts say is growing rapidly in the private sector as well. The two marines, Lance Cpl. John Mayfield 3d, 20, of Dallas, and Cpl. Joseph Vlacovsky, 24, of Stark, Ohio, refused to comply with an order to submit blood and tissue from the mouth for DNA identification in February 1995. They said they were deeply uncomfortable about how the information might be used.

headline.main: 2 Marines Who Refused to Comply With Genetic-Testing Order Face aCourt-Martial

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Re "Clear Antitrust Rules for Doctors" (editorial, April 9): Using the legal subterfuge that physicians should be prohibited from networking, as this avoids financial risk, you praise managed care companies for forcing medical costs downward. What you do not state is that they function as insurance companies that assume no risk after skimming a percentage of premiums for profit.

headline.main: Keep Medicare Out of Managed-Care Hands

docs.lead_paragraph: IN the home gym that was once a two-car garage but is now carpeted and freshly painted, there is a cushioned board known as a tilt table. A quadriplegic can be strapped onto it and swiveled upright to about 75 degrees, to reacquaint his feet with the weight of his dead limbs. "If you don't keep working on your body, muscles atrophy," the man who had the gym built said. "Bones become brittle and unable to take weight. All of this is in preparation for walking, of course."

headline.main: AT HOME WITH: Christopher Reeve;Will the Insurers Feel His Sting?

docs.lead_paragraph: Clerical workers at Barnard College began their second strike in two months yesterday over differences that both sides said were small. A few of the 150 strikers acknowledged that they would lose more pay from a short strike than they would gain by having Barnard accept all their demands. Nonetheless, the strikers, who include clerical and library workers and dormitory desk attendants, insisted that it was worth walking out again because, in their view, high principles were at stake.

docs.lead_paragraph: The anti-lock brake systems look out of place as they slide by almost silently on conveyor belts at the ITT Industries factory here. From the spotless white floors to the cool, filtered air to the young workers in white hair nets and white plastic laboratory coats, the factory seems more suited to the production of computer components than auto parts. Far different are the cavernous buildings in Dayton, Ohio, filled with endless rows of clanking, roaring machinery, where the General Motors Corporation makes brakes for nearly all its cars and trucks. A few rusting fans hang from the exposed support beams, the only relief when temperatures soar above 100 degrees in the summer. The floors are concrete painted black, and the air smells of oil and sweat. The workers, mostly graying men in their 40's and 50's, wear greasy orange jump suits or blue jeans -- and nobody has a hairnet.

headline.main: Need to Cut Costs? Order Out;Outsourcing Saves Money, but Labor Is Frustrated

docs.lead_paragraph: IS the drug your doctor has prescribed the best one for your condition? Do you want to know the benefits and drawbacks of each treatment option that your doctor has given you? How can you challenge your insurance company if it refuses to pay for a therapy that your doctor recommends? Until recently finding answers to questions like these demanded a lot of legwork in the form of trips to a medical library, and information about insurance practices was hard to find anywhere. But now the answers are within reach of anyone with an Internet connection.

headline.main: On-Line Health Information Yields Vast Mountains of Gems and Junk

docs.lead_paragraph: The Olympic torch is on its way, but if it arrived today there would be nothing to light. The city is so pockmarked with construction sites that contractors find themselves begging for backhoes. And for the moment, Atlanta's new 21-acre Centennial Park would be usable only if the International Olympic Committee added mud wrestling as a demonstration sport. Starting on July 19, 100 days from Wednesday, Atlanta will be host to the 26th Olympic Games. There is still an awful lot to do. And while the excitement is palpable throughout the city, polls show that anticipation coexists here with rising anxiety and frustration.

headline.main: Anxiety for Atlantans, But Officials Are Upbeat
